thread.title_full: Rip-off annuity broker fees could be capped as FCA plans crackdown

title: Rip-off annuity broker fees could be capped as FCA plans crackdown
text:
0.00 0.00 
A cap on non-advised annuity fees could boost savers' pensions by thousands of pounds and has been welcomed by the Pensions Minister 
Rip-off annuity brokers should have their fees capped, the City watchdog has suggested, as it sets out plans to limit excessive commissions for first time. 
The crackdown, proposed by the Financial Conduct Authority and welcomed by the Pensions Minister, could boost savers' retirement funds by thousands of pounds. 
Evidence suggests hundreds of thousands of savers who buy annuities through “shopping around” services are unknowingly paying more in charges than those who hire a financial adviser, despite receiving a less valuable service. 
A rule change in 2013 means financial advisers must disclose their fees upfront, but as annuity brokers still get paid using complicated commission models, it is more difficult for savers to tell how much they are being charged. 
The FCA says the cap could be introduced as early as 2017 with industry insiders predicting it will limit commissions at 2pc of someone's fund, around the average level savers can expect to pay for full financial advice. 
•Pension fees cap could add £1bn to savers' pots 
•Over-55s losing £10,000 to pension withdrawal fees 'lottery' 
•Excessive pension fund fees capped by minister 
A 2pc cap would force the UK’s biggest annuity broker, Hargreaves Lansdown (LSE: HL.L - news ) , to reduce its commissions as it currently charges up to 2.45pc of someone’s fund for non-advised annuity broking services. 
Savers buying ill-health annuities pay the highest fees and in the most extreme cases they are paying up to 6pc, or £6,000 from a £100,000 pension pot, according to a study conducted by the FCA’s Consumer Panel. 
The report also found non-advised services ranged in quality, with many appearing to use limited panels of providers which do not give savers the best deals, while others operate “superficial” calculations for ill-health rates. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) said: “Non-advice services [brokers] are often more profitable than advice services [financial advisers] because they have lower delivery costs, yet can often charge more, especially for ill health annuities.” 
Before being appointed Pensions Minister in May, Baroness Ros Altmann repeatedly hit out at annuity brokers, saying they should be banned because savers would be better off hiring financial advisers instead. 
Last night she said: “I warmly welcome the FCA’s investigation into non-advised annuity sales. Customers who are buying annuities need to understand how much they’re paying, and the risks involved. 
“Unfortunately many consumers have purchased an unsuitable annuity without financial advice and paid significant sums in commission without realising it. It is really important to protect consumers and ensure they can get good value from their pension savings.”

Data from the Association of British Insurers, the trade body which represents insurers, shows around 70pc of savers who buy an annuity do not take financial advice. 
Alan Higham, founder of pensionschamp.com, said: “The FCA should ban commission all together and introduce upfront fees instead. Commissions only serve to confuse the customer and the only time they see how much they are paying at a very late stage.” 
Billy Burrows, an independent retirement expert, estimates people who buy non-advised annuities are typically paying up to £500 more than the average saver who pays for full advice. 
The FCA is also considering updating information it sends out to people approaching their retirement date, making clearer to savers the costs and benefits of shopping around for annuity deals, over sticking with their insurer. 
In April the Government introduced a 0.75pc cap on excessive pension management charges to boost savers’ retirement funds by £1 billion, as part of a Government initiative to tackle “rip-off” levies that deplete customers’ savings. 
The FCA will now collect further evidence on annuity commissions and has begun an industry consultation on whether a cap should be introduced which ends in January. 
A Treasury spokesman said: “We want to ensure that our financial services sector supports working people at every stage of their lives. 
“That’s why we’ve launched a major new review into financial advice to explore what more can be done to make sure people can access high quality, affordable, tailored advice and guidance so they can make informed decisions with their hard-earned money.” 
Have you been ripped off by excessive charges on your pension? We want to hear about it. Email: katie.morley@telegraph.co.uk
